msgSnippet: Too true. No amount of UI, documentation and fancy API can tell you when and why to test. For that, you need either experience or a coach. I think this

Too true. No amount of UI, documentation and fancy API can tell you "when"
and "why" to test. For that, you need either experience or a coach. I think
this mailing list provides the necessary coaching. The XP mailing lists
provide even more.

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>

Jim Cheesman <jchees@...> on 07/11/2001 10:59:10

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To:   junit@yahoogroups.com
cc:
Subject:  Re: [junit] Support for JUnit



At 04:40 PM 11/07/01, you wrote:
>I am not an agent of JUnit. What follows is my opinion and nothing more.
>
>JUnit is so simple that there is no need for support of any kind, beyond
>this mailing list. I hope that JUnit always stays as simple as it is now,
>so that it never needs support.
>
>That's the beauty of JUnit: its simplicity.


I'm inclined to agree... up to a point ;) Using JUnit is a matter of
learning a new API - I don't think that support per se is really needed, at
most maybe some classes on how to set up the tests.

Why up to a point? Because the api is only the "how" of testing - learning
the "when" and "why" is another matter...
